I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Managing for development results (MfDR) is an approach to management that orients 
policies, institutions, and individuals to focus more on results than activities and inputs. MfDR 
approaches are integral to international efforts to sustain development effectiveness, and the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) has funded capacity development on MfDR in Asia and the 
Pacific for over a decade. ADB’s action plan on MfDR 2009–2011 defines its approach to 
increasing development effectiveness through MfDR on three fronts: (i) strengthening MfDR 
approaches in developing member countries (DMCs), (ii) mainstreaming MfDR in ADB as an 
institution, and (iii) promoting joint MfDR activities with other development partners.1 The action 
plan supports the Paris Declaration on Aid Effectiveness which stresses that the ―capacity to 
plan,  manage,  implement,  and  account  for  results  of  policies  and  programs  is  critical  for 
achieving development objectives.‖2 
  
2.  To assist DMCs on MfDR, ADB has supported the Asia–Pacific Community of Practice 
on MfDR (APCoP) since 2005. APCoP aims to empower key individuals, working together in a 
network or community of practice (CoP), to act as effective change agents to mainstream MfDR 
approaches into public sector management (PSM) and its functions—planning, budgeting, and 
monitoring and evaluation (M&E). ADB’s initiative in supporting a DMC-oriented regional CoP 
has been emulated by the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank in their 
support for regional African and Latin American CoPs. The three regional CoPs coordinate 
activities through a global partnership on MfDR sponsored by the Development Assistance 
Committee of the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development. 
 
3.  APCoP  was  launched  under  a  small-scale  technical  assistance  (TA)  project  by  26 
leading results management practitioners from 11 countries.3 APCoP’s activities are guided by a 
coordinating committee consisting of senior DMC government officials. Following a 6-month 
pilot project, members reiterated their strong commitment to sustain the initiative and requested 
ADB to continue support. The regional TA for Community of Practice for Development Results – 
Phase II was prepared in 2006 and its implementation has seen APCoP grow to 26 participating 
countries with 700 members.4  The Results Management Unit of the ADB Strategy and Policy 
Department is the secretariat, providing technical support, organizing activities, and managing 
the budget. At the 2009 APCoP annual meeting in Malaysia, members requested ADB to 
continue its support. The proposed regional capacity development TA responds to members’ 
requests that APCoP support be strengthened at the country level. The design and monitoring 
framework (Appendix 1) reflects lessons learned from the earlier ADB support.5    
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  A  results-based  PSM  system  is  key  to  development  effectiveness  as  it  enables 
governments  to  make  informed  decisions  to  sustain  development  outcomes.  Yet  public 
expenditure reviews persistently highlight weak PSM in DMCs, which constrains the delivery 
and assessment of development initiatives. In addition, PSM capacity development is often

short term and suffers from inadequate attention to (i) the links between the PSM functions of 
planning, budgeting, implementation, and M&E; (ii) coordination of all functions around shared 
results; and (iii) coordination across all government institutions around shared results. MfDR 
introduces features that, when applied to PSM, will enable DMCs to make informed decisions 
on future development actions. 
 
5.  Furthermore,  demand-driven  MfDR  capacity  development  initiatives  and  the  use  of 
country systems are central to country ownership and hence to the sustainability of outcomes. 
Yet, DMCs often see capacity initiatives as supply driven, solely promoting international good 
practices in a "one size fits all" approach rather than building on existing country systems. This 
has frequently resulted in supply-driven initiatives that have been implemented sporadically, 
with the following consequences for the DMC PSM functions: 
 
(i)  National,  sector,  and  subnational  planning  systems  and  processes  are  not 
integrated in a results chain with common indicators and targets. 
(ii)  Budgets are focused on inputs, which are insufficiently aligned with the activities 
linked to the outputs and outcomes from the planning process. 
(iii)  Implementation is not sufficiently focused on priority outputs and outcomes. 
(iv)  Monitoring  is  weak  due  to  inadequate  systems  and  procedures  resulting  in 
unavailable, untimely, or inaccurate baseline and performance data. In addition, 
monitoring is often limited to tracking procurement and disbursement or collecting 
data on activities, rather than on indicators to measure outputs and outcomes 
against established targets. 
(v)  Weaknesses  in  MfDR  integration  across  the  PSM  functions  of  planning, 
budgeting, and monitoring hinder effective evaluation that would better inform 
planning. This makes transparent and evidence-based decision making difficult. 
 
6.  While the TA for Community of Practice for Development Results – Phase II sought to 
resolve these issues, its design also recognized the importance of a phased approach to ensure 
APCoP responds to the long-term and varying capacity development needs of its members. A 
review undertaken in June 2010 noted that the regional TA had successfully delivered all of its 
four  targeted  outputs,  and  exceeded  expected  performance  in  three  out  of  four  planned 
outcomes.6 The delivered outputs were (i) a sustained and broadened regional APCoP-MfDR 
with  a  critical  mass  of  practitioners  at  the  working  level;  (ii)  established  country-  and 
subregional-based CoPs; (iii) publication of MfDR good practice papers and contributions to an 
MfDR sourcebook, and (iv) a regional training hub in results-based monitoring and evaluation. 
 
7.  For outcomes, the regional TA (i) demonstrated that a CoP on MfDR is an innovative 
and  effective  modality,  (ii)  increased  capacity  and  demand  for  MfDR  in  DMCs,  and  (iii) 
increased dissemination of MfDR knowledge products. The review considered the achievement 
of the fourth outcome—the delivery of strengthened M&E systems in DMCs—would require 
more interventions that are targeted at the country-level.  
 
8.  The regional TA developed the capacity of a critical mass of senior government officials 
across the region as change agents for MfDR. The regional TA successfully increased APCoP 
members’ ownership by (i) strengthening the role of the coordinating committee in guiding the 
work program, (ii) increasing the exposure of members to international best practices, and (iii) 
promoting  peer-to-peer  learning.  It  also  helped  create  knowledge  resources,  such  as 
publications, newsletters, and a website. The APCoP website hosts online discussions and

3 
stores information on MfDR and members’ activities and publications. The 2009 APCoP source 
book, Moving from Concept to Action, has been internationally recognized.7  
 
9.  To build on past achievement and respond to members’ demands, the coordinating 
committee has requested ADB support to expand and consolidate APCoP so that APCoP can 
more effectively support MfDR mainstreaming and meet the remaining challenges (para. 5). 
More specifically, the coordinating committee noted the need to supplement regional activities 
with concrete follow-up actions by members at the country level. This is the key to ensuring that 
results-based approaches are mainstreamed into the PSM of DMCs in a sustainable manner. In 
addition, the coordinating committee highlighted the importance of (i) reaching out to more 
DMCs not actively engaged in the TA for Community of Practice for Development Results – 
Phase II; (ii) sustaining the website and knowledge products to record and share best practices 
for members; and (iii) expanding centers of excellence in the region (beyond the Singapore Civil 
Service College and the Shanghai International Program of Development Evaluation Training) 
to provide increased venues for MfDR training and seminars. The coordinating committee noted 
that, while ongoing capacity development initiatives at the regional level would require continued 
funding by development partners, demonstrated success in MfDR integration at the country 
level should be mainstreamed into country-led initiatives that are self-sustainable. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The desired impact of the TA is to further advance MfDR in countries with APCoP 
members. This will be demonstrated by an increased number of participating countries with key 
attributes of MfDR in place over baseline of 2010.  The intended outcome is the increased 
application of MfDR by APCoP members in their country contexts. The outcome will be seen in 
(i) the increased numbers of members applying MfDR principles and approaches, and (ii) the 
implementation of plans for the integration of MfDR into PSM. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  This TA supports APCoP members through regional and country activities focused on 
introducing  results-based  approaches  to  PSM.  Regionally,  the  TA  will  continue  to  support 
members through workshops and other training events to share ideas on best practices. At the 
country level it will help APCoP members incorporate MfDR into their country PSM systems. To 
achieve its outcome, this TA will deliver four specific outputs: knowledge products on MfDR 
created and disseminated, increased MfDR capacity of APCoP members, an expanded APCoP 
membership, and plans for MfDR approaches in PSM approved by relevant DMC authority. 
 
12.  To develop, create, and disseminate knowledge products, a number of key activities will 
be  financed  under  the  TA.  Knowledge  products  will  be  distilled  from  the  experience  of 
members—captured through summaries of online discussions—and developed as cases from 
workshop and meeting sessions, as well as experiences with country initiatives. The existing 
APCoP online virtual resource center will continue to facilitate knowledge storage, sharing, and 
dissemination. Knowledge will also be disseminated through training modules and publications.

excellence—which support knowledge sharing, skills development and peer-to-peer learning for 
the APCoP members—will be expanded to include the ADB Institute in Japan and training 
facilities in Malaysia. The TA will promote members’ access to expertise on MfDR in PSM by 
building networks of qualified national, regional, and global MfDR experts. The virtual resource 
center  will  continue  as  an  important  vehicle  for  the  members  to  discuss  and  share  their 
experiences and expertise on MfDR. 
 
14.  The TA will strengthen and broaden the APCoP membership to include a larger number 
of active members. A strong emphasis of the TA for Community of Practice for Development 
Results – Phase II was to encourage membership from senior government officials who can act 
as change agents for MfDR. The TA will continue to streamline the current membership and at 
the same time broaden it so that the APCoP membership reflects all of the core functions of 
PSM—planning, budgeting, implementation, and M&E. The TA will reinforce the coordinating 
committee’s role by providing a technical coordinator to assist in monitoring feedback from 
members on their activities and responding to their needs in the design of regional activities. 
 
15.  The TA’s most significant output will be the country-specific capacity development plans 
to  be  developed  by  members.  Support  for  the  country  initiatives  will  follow  an  innovative 
country-based  CoP  approach.  This  bottom-up  approach  will  strengthen  the  ownership, 
accountability, and sustainability of capacity development initiatives. The CoPs will comprise 
senior government officials from the central (planning and finance) and sector ministries, and 
may also include technical experts and civil service organizations. Support for the country-
based CoPs will bring members together to work on PSM systems and processes identified as 
hampering the effective delivery of the national plan. CoPs will focus on national, subnational, or 
sector PSM issues. They will establish country standards, analyze gaps, and formulate capacity 
development plans that build on existing country systems and international good practices. For 
example,  to  strengthen  national  monitoring  systems,  a  cross-sector  CoP  of  government 
individuals working in monitoring will be supported to formulate the capacity development plan 
for the national monitoring system. Initial support to implement the plans may come through 
loans and TA from development partners, but longer-term sustainable support is expected 
through  the  government's  own  initiatives.  A  country-driven  capacity  development  plan  will 
strengthen harmonization of capacity development assistance between development partners.  
 
16.  At  least  four  DMCs  (including  the  following:  Bangladesh,  Bhutan,  Cambodia,  the 
People’s  Republic  of  China,  Fiji  Islands,  Indonesia,  Kyrgyz  Republic,  the  Lao  People’s 
Democratic  Republic,  Maldives,  Mongolia,  Nepal,  Pakistan,  Samoa,  Sri  Lanka,  Tajikistan, 
Uzbekistan, and Vanuatu) will be supported under the TA to work on selected MfDR issues, 
financing workshops, and seminars to develop plans. The TA will also support members of 
country-based CoPs to interact with the wider APCoP to promote sharing of experiences and 
good practices. After this initial support, it is expected that the country-based CoP activities will 
be incorporated into the DMC’s own regular processes. The success of the country-based CoPs 
in promoting MfDR approaches will be documented so that this modality can be replicated by 
other DMCs and other development partners. Robust and results-oriented PSM systems will 
help  development  partners  overcome  the  challenge  of  aligning  their  country  development 
strategies  with  those  of  the  DMC,  and  demonstrating  the  contribution  of  each  partner’s 
strategies to the DMC national development goals. Written confirmation of no-objection will be 
obtained from the governments of DMCs where CoP-MfDR activities will be undertaken.  
 
17.  For maximum impact, each of the DMCs supported during 2011–2013 will be from a 
subregional group within Asia and the Pacific. The selected DMCs will have (i) weak PSM 
functions  that  constrain  the  delivery  of  development  programs;  (ii)  expressed  demand  for

5 
development partners to support PSM strengthening; (iii) effective change agents such as a 
central ministry championing MfDR, and a sector institution interested in or implementing MfDR 
approaches; (iv) interest in the CoP modality; (v) a pipeline of projects funded internally or 
through development partners that could support identified MfDR approaches and CoP activities 
in the long term; and (vi) the potential capacity to implement the MfDR approaches chosen.  
 
18.  There are a number of risks and assumptions associated with the outputs and outcome 
of the TA, as listed in the design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1). At the outcome level, 
it is assumed that there will be appropriate financial resources to implement the country-based 
plans for MfDR implementation, since this is one of the criteria for country selection. However, 
there is also a risk that there may be a lack of capacity within the government to implement the 
interventions associated with the MfDR plan. This will be mitigated through the other outputs of 
the CoP-MfDR, especially those dealing with peer-to-peer and expert support. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
19.  The total cost of the R-CDTA is estimated at $520,000. The TA will be financed on a 
grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV $310,000 and TASF-other 
sources $210,000). Additional cofinancing may be obtained from another funding source which 
is to be determined. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
20.  ADB,  through  the  Results  Unit  of  the  Strategy  and  Policy  Department,  will  be  the 
executing agency of the TA and will be responsible for overall management and monitoring of 
the activities. The Results Unit will work in close coordination with the Regional and Sustainable 
Development Department, regional departments, and resident missions. 
 
21.  The TA will be implemented over 14 months, commencing in January 2011 and ending 
in March 2012. It will need one international consultant, on an intermittent basis, as a technical 
coordinator for the duration of the regional TA (up to 6 person-months of work). The technical 
coordinator  will  be  responsible  for  (i)  liaising  with  and  supporting  coordinating  committee 
members, (ii) responding to technical and functional queries, (iii) directing online and seminar-
based capacity development, (iv) updating the virtual resources center, (v) facilitating country-
based CoP interventions, (vi) supporting the production of publications, and (vii) linking the 
Asia–Pacific CoP-MfDR with other regional CoPs. Two full-time national consultants will be 
required for financial, administrative, and research support (up to 14 person-months each). 
High-quality, experienced international consultants will support the country-CoP-driven PSM 
interventions in the selected DMCs, and will be engaged on an intermittent basis (about 1 
person-months of work in total). All consultants will be recruited on an individual basis  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time). The outline terms of reference for consultants is in Appendix 3. Confirmation of no-
objection of DMC governments will be obtained before the commencement or financing of 
activities in the territories of the concerned DMCs.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Technical Coordinator of the Asia–Pacific Community of Practice on Managing for 
Development Results (international, 6 person-months) 
 
1.  The regional capacity development technical assistance (TA) requires an international 
consultant  to  act  as  TA  coordinator  to  perform  a  full  range  of  technical  coordination  and 
administration functions to ensure successful delivery of expected TA outputs. The detailed 
tasks are as follows:  
 
(i)  Introduce  results-based  approaches  to  public  sector  management  (PSM)  in 
developing member countries (DMCs) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). 
(ii)  Help coordinate country-level managing for development results (MfDR) activities 
with ADB's regional departments. 
(iii)  Help  draft,  write,  and  disseminate  MfDR  knowledge  products,  including  the 
Sourcebook  2011  published  by  the  Asia–Pacific  Community  of  Practice  on 
Managing for Development Results (APCoP). 
(iv)  Maintain good and regular communication with APCoP coordinating committee 
members and provide them with updates and information on TA activities. 
(v)  Help design, implement, monitor, and report all TA outputs in accordance with 
the design and monitoring framework.  
 
2.  The  technical  coordinator  should  have  global  experience  in  MfDR,  especially  in 
developing countries, with practical experience working with CoP members and introducing a 
results-based approach in PSM in Asia and the Pacific.  
 
B.  Expert  Support  to  the  Asia–Pacific  Community  of  Practice  on  Managing  for 
Development Results (international, 1 person-month) 
 
3.  An international consultant will be engaged to provide expert support to the CoP-MfDR. 
The  consultant  will  facilitate  online  discussions,  seminars,  workshops,  and  study  tours  as 
necessary. The consultant’s specific tasks include the following: 
 
(i)  Support APCoP discussions by designing online programs, workshops, seminars, 
and study tours. 
(ii)  Introduce international experiences on MfDR, bringing in concrete solutions and 
practices from developed and developing country experiences. 
(iii)  Design  and  implement seminars,  workshops,  and  study  tours,  and  providing 
support, guidance, and feedback to CoP member participants. 
(iv)  Support online discussions by designing discussion topics, providing comments, 
and  posting  solutions,  guiding  participants  to  examples  and  materials,  and 
stimulating member participation. 
 
4.  The  consultant  should  have  global  experience  in  MfDR,  especially  in  developing 
countries, with practical experience working with CoP members and introducing a results-based 
approach to PSM in Asia and the Pacific.

10  Appendix 3 
 
C.  Technical Assistance Project Analyst for the Asia–Pacific Community of Practice 
on Managing for Development Results (national, 14 person-months) 
 
5.  The TA project analyst will provide administrative and analytical support to the Technical 
Assistance Supervising Unit and in TA administration in general. The main responsibility is to 
coordinate the administrative, technical, and logistical aspects of all TA activities. Detailed tasks 
are as follows:  
 
(i)  Monitor physical and financial progress of TA implementation. 
(ii)  Provide  logistical  support  to  MfDR  workshops  and  conferences,  including 
preparation  of  draft  correspondence,  budget  estimates,  participants’ 
accommodation and travel arrangements, payment of allowances, and collection 
and dissemination of meeting materials and outputs. 
(iii)  Prepare requests for payment and liquidation of expenses for TA activities. 
(iv)  Help country-based CoPs process requests for disbursements and make the 
CoP website a functional channel for communicating country actions for results. 
(v)  Help maintain the CoP-MfDR website by providing inputs and uploading MfDR 
materials, and coordinate with CoP members on website content and updates. 
(vi)  Update and maintain TA management and project documents. 
 
D.  Research and Evaluation Specialist for the Asia–Pacific Community of Practice on 
Managing for Development Results (national, 14 person-months) 
 
6.  The research and evaluation specialist will provide technical support to help mainstream 
MfDR approaches in developing member countries. The detailed tasks include the following: 
 
(i)  Help organize APCoP country workshops, including preparing and implementing 
workshops, drafting agendas, taking minutes, and drafting reports and speeches. 
(ii)  Prepare background papers, including country analysis of MfDR support by ADB 
and other donors as well as proposed concept notes for MfDR assistance, and 
provide other research support on MfDR and PSM, as necessary. 
(iii)  Participate in MfDR and PSM-related meetings, and review related reports and 
papers.  
(iv)  Work with the project analyst to update TA reporting requirements for ADB, help 
monitor technical expert contracts and other financial matters relating to the 
MfDR TA projects, and review and update the MFDR website and newsletter 
content. 
 
E.  Website  Expert  for  the  Asia–Pacific  Community  of  Practice  on  Managing  for 
Development Results (national, 1 person-month) 
 
7.  The website expert’s work will focus on the technical aspect of improving the APCoP-
MfDR website. Detailed tasks include the following:  
 
(i)  Perform a website inventory, propose improvements, and implement changes on 
website  layout  design;  upload  and  index  files  using  improved  classification; 
provide links to CoP materials and make them searchable on the MfDR website; 
and improve usability of CoP online services. 
(ii)  Prepare layout design for the semiannual issue of the CoP brochure, quarterly e-
newsletter, and other MfDR promotional materials.

(iii)  Provide inputs on website content, publications, and e-newsletter and coordinate 
with MfDR web administrator on the integration of the CoP library, and respond 
to technical issues as may be raised by CoP-MfDR members.
